docs.lead_paragraph: John Crescenzo is a 44-year-old truck driver with two children, a deadly disease and a health insurance plan that won't pay to help keep him alive. He paid the $6,000 premium out of his own pocket, choosing Wellcare, an insurer that advertises a commitment to small business. Last May, Mr. Crescenzo noticed a large lump on his thigh. His Wellcare doctors eventually diagnosed it as a sarcoma, a rare form of cancer, and tried chemotherapy and then surgery to remove the tumor. But by then it had spread to his lungs.

headline.main: One Man's Battle With Managed Care

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by New York Lt Gov Betsy McCaughey Ross on case history of John Crescenzo, cancer patient, as illustration of managed care's arbitrary decisions on experimental treatments; says New York lawmakers should guarantee patients' right to appeal to medical experts outside their plan (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the last few years, the debate over the future of Social Security has been cast largely in terms of what should be done to prevent the system itself from running out of money after baby boomers start retiring early in the next century. But now, with the much-delayed report of a Federal advisory panel on Social Security ready for release, perhaps as early as Monday, a much more significant fault line is finally coming into focus. Ultimately at stake in the debate over how to solve the program's long-term financial problems, say those on both sides of the trenches, is a choice that will shape the very nature of the American economy in the decades ahead.

headline.main: Trying to Slice the National Pie and Mend Social Security, Too

docs.abstract: Analysis of debate over future of Social Security; on one side are those who argue that Social Security should be transformed gradually into hybrid public-private system that encourages people to save more for their own retirement; on other side are those who fear that any profound change in way Social Security is structured would put the 'haves' against the 'have-nots,' and that recasting nation's public retirement system into something resembling collection of private 401(k) accounts would only accelerate trend of recent decades toward greater inequality in United States; much-delayed report of Federal advisory panel on Social Security is expected to be released shortly (M)
docs.snippet: For the last few years, the debate over the future of Social Security has been cast largely in terms of what should be done to prevent the system itself from running out of money after baby boomers start retiring early in the next century.    But...

docs.lead_paragraph: Very few consumers of prescription drugs are aware of the existence of pharmaceutical benefit managers, the large and increasingly powerful companies that handle the purchase and distribution of prescription drugs for many H.M.O.'s and insurance companies. In their zeal to enhance profits, the benefit managers, known as P.B.M.'s, have come up with a variety of incentives and penalties to convince doctors and pharmacists to substitute a drug preferred by the P.B.M. for the one originally prescribed. Commercial considerations, especially the financial relationships between the P.B.M.'s and drug manufacturers, are the primary factors in determining which drugs are preferred.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert column draws attention to potential problems posed by pharmaceutical benefit managers, large and increasingly powerful companies that handle purchase and distribution of prescription drugs for many HMO's and insurance companies; warns that in their zeal to enhance profits, benefit managers, known as PBM's, have come up with variety of incentives and penalties to convince doctors and pharmacists to substitute a drug preferred by PBM for one originally prescribed; points out that commercial considerations, especially financial relationships between PBM's and drug manufacturers, are primary factors in determining which drugs are preferred (M)
docs.snippet: Very few consumers of prescription drugs are aware of the existence of pharmaceutical benefit managers, the large and increasingly powerful companies that handle the purchase and distribution of prescription drugs for many H.M.O.'s and insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: As managed care is being criticized for cutting hospital stays short and penalizing doctors who order expensive procedures, a legislative committee here has found that managed care seems to be working well, with few complaints from consumers. A report from the Legislature's Program Review and Investigations Committee said that managed care was reducing health care costs in Connecticut while satisfying consumers. And the report found no evidence to back up many of the harshest complaints made about managed care at public hearings before the Legislature earlier this year.

headline.main: Legislative Panel Describes H.M.O.'s as Working Well

docs.abstract: Connecticut legislative committee reports that managed care is reducing health care costs in Connecticut while satisfying consumers; finds no evidence to back up many of harshest complaints made about managed care at public hearings before Legislature earlier this year (M)
docs.snippet: As managed care is being criticized for cutting hospital stays short and penalizing doctors who order expensive procedures, a legislative committee here has found that managed care seems to be working well, with few complaints from consumers.    A...

docs.lead_paragraph: YESTERDAY,'' sang the elderly woman in a long frilly dress. ''Yesterday.'' Her voice echoed through a ballroom in Brooklyn where two dozen members of the Senior League of Flatbush sat listening. Suddenly she stopped, flustered. ''I can't remember the words,'' she said, shaking her head. But she was not easily defeated. After burrowing among papers, she happily clutched a song sheet and in a moment was back at the microphone.

headline.main: Centers for Elderly Enter a New Age

docs.abstract: Senior centers are struggling with new and daunting challenges as demand for centers and services grow and government cuts back financial support; increasing diversity of clients, who range from lively 60's to frail 80's and include immigrants and handicapped, is forcing centers to stretch; many have abandoned social-club beginnings to provide support groups, other services; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It's 10 A.M., and the parents of some 90 infants, toddlers and preschoolers in this white-collar suburb about an hour's drive southwest of Manhattan know exactly where their children are. Life within the cheerful, pristine confines of Kindercare's ''learning center'' is safe, cozy and, above all, predictable. On this sunny, not-too-chilly morning, the older children are busy attacking the plastic playground equipment, while inside the 3-year-olds are puzzling over cut-paper shapes and the babies are snoozing in their green and white cribs. In the kitchen, the cook is preparing pizza-like ''Italian dippers'' with broccoli for lunch from a four-week rotation that runs from meat loaf to toasted cheese.

headline.main: Parents Most in Need May Have the Least Access

docs.abstract: Obstacles to financial success in child care business are substantial, quandary that reflects both problematic economics of day care and a cultural failure to adjust to consequences of expecting mothers with young children to work; care of the sort provided by Kindercare Learning Centers' Clark, NJ, facility--$150 to $205 a week--is out of financial reach of many families; and many others do not want it: though experts say preschoolers benefit from social context and stimulation of quality care, many working parents prefer to re-create, with mother-surrogate, a more traditional setting, even if it offers little more than baby-sitting; tables; graphs; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Government has adopted a new policy limiting the types of bonuses that can be paid to doctors as a reward for controlling the cost of services for Medicare and Medicaid patients. The policy is described in notices sent today to health maintenance organizations around the country. Its stated purpose is ''to protect patients against improper clinical decisions made under the influence of strong financial incentives'' offered to doctors by H.M.O.'s.

headline.main: U.S. PLACES LIMITS ON H.M.O. BONUSES FOR COST CUTTERS

docs.abstract: Federal Government adopts new policy limiting the types of bonuses that can be paid to doctors as a reward for controlling the cost of services for Medicare and Medicaid patients; policy seeks to protect patients against improper clinical decisions made under the influence of strong financial incentives offered to doctors by health maintenance organizations; is expected to set wider standard for the entire managed-care industry (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BECAUSE of the increased volatility in the market and signs of a possible slowdown in the economy, some Wall Street advisers are telling investors to focus on companies with predictable profits that are not dependent on an expanding economy. To be sure, stocks are not far off their records, and they rebounded strongly last week after the small selloff earlier this month. And some analysts say earnings will continue to be strong next year. Still, over the last few months, big stocks have generally performed better than small issues, which are perceived as more speculative.

headline.main: Economy not expanding? Some companies don't mind.

docs.abstract: Because of increased volatility in market and signs of possible slowdown in economy, some Wall Street advisers are telling investors to focus on companies with predictable profits that are not dependent on expanding economy (Market Place) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of 220,000 Medicare patients has found that people who suffer heart attacks are more likely to survive if they are treated by cardiologists rather than doctors practicing general medicine. The findings raise concern about insurance companies' growing reliance on doctors rendering primary care rather than on specialists.
docs.abstract: Study of 220,000 Medicare patients has found that people who suffer heart attacks are more likely to survive if they are treated by cardiologists rather than doctors practicing general medicine (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The hand of St. Irene -- or what worshipers believe to be the remains of it -- rests on a bed of red velvet in an engraved silver box carefully balanced atop an altar pedestal in a Greek Orthodox church in Astoria, Queens. To the untrained eye, it is nothing but a piece of bone immersed in beeswax, and some doubt it is from the saint. But to the legions of faithful who go to see it every Sunday at St. Irene Chrysovalantou Greek Orthodox Cathedral -- a small church that belongs to a splinter branch of Greek orthodoxy -- the hand is a holy relic, a powerful symbol that their beloved saint has followed them to their new home in America not only in spirit but also in body.

headline.main: Relic Brings Clout and Miracle Seekers to a Queens Church
headline.kicker: The Power of St. Irene's Hand

docs.abstract: Legions of faithful travel to St Irene Chrysovalantou Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Astoria, Queens, to view what they consider a holy relic, remains of St Irene's hand; photo (M)
